rComments: this professor is a genius. do you have to work hard? oh yeah. but after the quarter is over you won't regret it. If your a literature major you have to take him before you graduate. Godzich is a pretty cool guy, he knows he's smart but here is always there to help in office hours.

Really, really fascinating teacher. Super fun to listen to, great readingsalthough there were a LOT of them. Make sure you are good at choosing what is and isn't important to read, because you will never get to write the essays if you try and actually do all of the reading. Bottom line: he's a genius, this was my favorite class all quarter.

Godzich is insightful, incredibly bright, and hilarious. He has ridiculously high standards that you have to rise to meet. You will drown in the reading but will learn an incomprehensible amount. Perfect way to end my Lit major at UCSC. If you are not excited at the idea of an intellectual ass-kicking, do not take a course with him.

Took this class for a GE but it's a lot more work than expected. Lots of books to read. It's also really hard to hear him (very quiet voice and heavy accent) even if you sit up front, and he often goes on long boring tangents. Very vague yet specific instructions for his papers.

If you're serious about studying literature, Godzich will become one of your favorite professors ever. He isn't afraid to challenge his students, is a wealth of information, and is a straight up genius who has worked with many of the major figures of Continental philosophy. His classes are wonderfully rigorous and I cannot recommend him enough.

I have taken two classes with Godzich - LIT 1 & African Novel. At first (especially with LIT 1) the readingssection & lecture don't seem cohesive, but he ties it all together at the end and will blow your mind! Really brilliant guy. Intimidating classes but really worth it. Sometimes you can afford to skip lecture, but they're super interesting

Calling this class a challenge doesn't do it justice... his lectures are about large scale ideas and you have to carefully read EVERYTHING and put it all together to even have a chance when writing your lengthy essays.  Do not take this class a G.E. He's a brilliant teacher and you'll learn a lot, but attend class and section religiously to succeed

I was never very involved with college until I took a course with Professor Godzich. He will work your but off, and will not take no for an answer. But the work is rewarding because he knows exactly what you need to learn and he secretly wants you to learn, but he just seems like an jerk if you treat him with disrespect. I did that, but dont.

I enjoy lit and I'm a good writer, but this class was the most time consuming course I have taken here so far. It didn't help that I'm a bio major and was taking chem and calc at the same time. I literally had no time to work on my assignments, which by the way are ridiculously long. DO NOT TAKE THIS CLASS UNLESS YOU'RE A LIT MAJOR!!!

Class really changed my ideas about reading and writing, not too reading heavy. Godzich lectures are fairly intense but worth a wealth of information.  One of my favorite literature classes, though the final paper was not easy! Mandatory attendance, though enforced with random pop quizzes.
Took Hermeneutics, Modernism and Medical Humanities. Professor Godzich is the most intelligent person I have ever met and one of the best lecturers. It is an honor to take his courses.
Awesome! Knowledgeable, helpful, inspiring and funny.

I just had to write about this class. Godzich is a GOD. No joke, he's one of the coolest teachers I've ever had, and hearing him speak made it worth it to go down to Oakes at 8am. However, the class is pretty difficult, so bring your A game and pay attention in section. Your TA will save you. All hail the great Godzich!

I actually care about this class enough to write a review.So,EVERYTHING IS EXTREMELY DIFFICULT IN THIS CLASS SO YOU WILL HAVE TO GO ABOVE AND BEYOND IF YOU WANT TO PASS.STICK TO YOUR TA LIKE A FLEA, CREATE STUDY GROUP, AND HAVE A TUTOR. These three things will be your savior.
Godzich is definitely a genius and his lectures are very interesting. There is a lot of writing and complex reading, so your TA will be your savior. This is not a class for the weak!

do not take this class with Wlad unless you are a lit major! hardest and most boring class i've taken at UCSC so far. his lectures dont have anything to do with the assignments. the essays are crazy and attendance is mandatory (at 8 Am). if you miss just one of the pop quizzes in lecture/section your grade will go down at least 4%.

Godzich is INSANE. I've never met anyone so brilliant in my entire life. The class is rediculos - only a midterm and a final, 2 two page papers and 3 two pagers. THEYRE IMPOSSIBLY HARD PROMPTS! There were no sections and office hours were a must. If you want to challenge yourself, take this class. Learning beneath Godzich was such a privilege.
Lecture it very very interesting, class was near impossible. Only two papers made up your entire grade and a TON of reading, and magically (as in no idea how) I got a B+. Found the class stressful

This man basically lives up to the first three letters in his last name: GOD. He knows everything and has been everywhere. Classes are usually engaging and challenging, definitely do the reading for his classes. He's a great lecturer, but his lectures really shine when he tells you about his personal life, which is epic.

Wlad's got the entire history of civilized man in his balding skull, and can speak more languages than you can  name. This is apparent in all his lectures. The question is, do you learn a lot from such a person? The answer is, if you want. If there's one thing I have to say, its that benefiting from his tremendous knowledge is really up to you.

Wlad is honestly one of the best teachers I have ever had due to his incredibly lecture skills! He has a way of weaving anecdotes in with factual knowledge like very few I have ever encountered...do the reading and try your best and you will be rewarded with a good grade. Wlad is an awesome teacher and I seriously recommend taking his class!

He by far one of the best teachers I've had at UCSC.  His lectures are always interesting and full of personal anecdotes, and he really knows his stuff.  There's a lot of reading, but most of it was interesting.  High writing expectations, but I never had trouble with the papers.  14-page final wasn't nearly as scary as I'd expected!

Godzich manages to match the astounding power of Dr. Eggman Robotnik with the reliability and factuality of Wikipedia. Regardless, I would recommend his class, I would recommend reading all the books he assigns, but I would not recommend picturing him naked.

Wlad is really intelligent guy, knows and loves what he lectures on. The readings are dense and sometimes very difficult, as are the assigned papers. If you're willing to put in the effort, it's a great class to take.
He is an amazing lecturer, but be warned, some of the readings are really difficult to get through.  Also, he expects a lot from your writing, making every essay a challenge.
oh my goodness he knows so much.  very smart. Hard concepts; i tried to do the reading, g ave up half way, still got a B, though. The concepts more important that the context, which is nice.

One of the key humanitarians of our time, with a more comprehensive knowledge than I'd thought possible; as powerful and as elusive as a legendary pokemon, it took me three classes to half-understand the awesome power of Godzich.

Wlad is very intelligent and a joy to listen to, but not at 8am. If you need to take Lit 101  take it with a different teacher. He is the only one that requires a 20 page final paper. It's also a very confusing reading load if you don't know anything about philosophy, and are only there for the literature. But no one takes attendance in lecture.

This hermeneutics course was very difficult, but I became a better writer for it. 4 papers, 3 rewrites mandatory, 24 page final paper and an in class terminology exam. The most stressful experience, but you learn. He is top of his field. Do it!

I took this class for a literature req. The topic was hermeneutics, which is a nice way of saying "an extremely long class about dead German men." If you're really into philosophy, then it's worth it. Godzich is an ok lecturer, he's kind of quiet but he's informative and cracks jokes sometimes. For the most part, I was bored.

The best professor at UCSC...he is more than amazing. Calling Wlad genius doesnt give him enough credit...his leactures will blow you away. His texts are difficult, but what he has to say about them will keep on you interested.

Outstanding teacher, endlessly informative. In a class on Derrida he was able to answer questions and objections fully and brilliantly. He gives off the impression of being humorless, but isn't. He once told us a story about Derrida's deconstruction of his (Wlad's) middle name (Bogusz). Has worked with many great philosophers and really knows his s
great lectures, well organized. Got me interested in Aristotle. Final was hard but fair.

Wlad is the best professor I have ever had. He is my academic idol. He knows everything and is an engaging lecturer who makes very difficult material very accessible. He might seem intimidating at first, but if  you go to his office hours he is very helpful and very funny. His classes were completely worth getting up for at 8 in the morning.

Wlad is a great lecturer... but with class at 8am MWF its hard to make it to class unless you feel that strongly about his stories. A must try for all LIT majors... a little too much philosophy for my taste. Four 2-3 page responses, choice of oral exam or 16-18pg paper for final... Like the grandpa you always wish you had.
Wlad is great. Other professors at UCSC should take note of someone who actually knows their stuff.

Wlad is amazing. He knows everything, or at least seeks to convey that impression. He's an amazing lecturer, being that he knows everything. He's not as good if you need to have a conversation, because he can't stop talking long enough to let you speak. But everyday I took a million pages of notes and learned so much that it was worthwhile.

For better or worse, Godzich's a lecturing machine.  He can talk forever about the material while throwing in interesting little anecdotes and stories; for instance, for his doctoral defense Foucault asked him a question with no preparation.  He grades pretty easily and doesn't seem to care whether you go to class.    You'll probably write a lot.

This man truly has a brilliant mind. He has worked with Derrida, DeLeuze, and Said, to name a few. I learned more in this class than all of last year. Derrida is confusing but he did as well as one can to explain his ideas. The course required 2 5pp papers and a 14-18pp final paper. He grades easily. I understood half the material and got an A.

I enjoyed Godzich's class on Derrida. I found him EXTREMELY well-informed, and as clear as someone explaining Derrida could hope to be. I also appreciated his interdisciplinary approach to the class. Definitely one of the most educational classes I've taken yet.
